trans-unit.source: API Management key concepts
trans-unit.target: API Management key concepts

trans-unit.source: Learn about APIs, products, roles, groups, and other API Management key concepts.
trans-unit.target: Learn about APIs, products, roles, groups, and other API Management key concepts.

trans-unit.source: What is API Management?
trans-unit.target: What is API Management?

trans-unit.source: API Management helps organizations publish APIs to external, partner and internal developers to unlock the potential of their data and services.
trans-unit.target: API Management helps organizations publish APIs to external, partner and internal developers to unlock the potential of their data and services.

trans-unit.source: Businesses everywhere are looking to extend their operations as a digital platform, creating new channels, finding new customers and driving deeper engagement with existing ones.
trans-unit.target: Businesses everywhere are looking to extend their operations as a digital platform, creating new channels, finding new customers and driving deeper engagement with existing ones.

trans-unit.source: API Management provides the core competencies to ensure a successful API program through developer engagement, business insights, analytics, security and protection.
trans-unit.target: API Management provides the core competencies to ensure a successful API program through developer engagement, business insights, analytics, security and protection.

trans-unit.source: To use API Management, administrators create APIs.
trans-unit.target: To use API Management, administrators create APIs.

trans-unit.source: Each API consists of one or more operations, and each API can be added to one or more products.
trans-unit.target: Each API consists of one or more operations, and each API can be added to one or more products.

trans-unit.source: To use an API, developers subscribe to a product that contains that API, and then they can call the API's operation, subject to any usage policies that may be in effect.
trans-unit.target: To use an API, developers subscribe to a product that contains that API, and then they can call the API's operation, subject to any usage policies that may be in effect.

trans-unit.source: This topic provides an overview of API Management key concepts.
trans-unit.target: This topic provides an overview of API Management key concepts.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] For more information, see the [Cloud-based API Management: Harnessing the Power of APIs](http://j.mp/ms-apim-whitepaper) PDF whitepaper.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] For more information, see the [Cloud-based API Management: Harnessing the Power of APIs](http://j.mp/ms-apim-whitepaper) PDF whitepaper.

trans-unit.target: This introductory whitepaper on API Management by CITO Research covers:

trans-unit.target: Common API requirements and challenges

trans-unit.target: Decoupling APIs and presenting facades

trans-unit.target: Getting developers up and running quickly

trans-unit.target: Securing access

trans-unit.target: Analytics and metrics

trans-unit.source: Azure API Management
trans-unit.target: Azure API Management

trans-unit.source: APIs and operations
trans-unit.target: APIs and operations

trans-unit.source: APIs are the foundation of an API Management service instance.
trans-unit.target: APIs are the foundation of an API Management service instance.

trans-unit.source: Each API represents a set of operations available to developers.
trans-unit.target: Each API represents a set of operations available to developers.

trans-unit.source: Each API contains a reference to the back-end service that implements the API, and its operations map to the operations implemented by the back-end service.
trans-unit.target: Each API contains a reference to the back-end service that implements the API, and its operations map to the operations implemented by the back-end service.

trans-unit.source: Operations in API Management are highly configurable, with control over URL mapping, query and path parameters, request and response content, and operation response caching.
trans-unit.target: Operations in API Management are highly configurable, with control over URL mapping, query and path parameters, request and response content, and operation response caching.

trans-unit.source: Rate limit, quotas, and IP restriction policies can also be implemented at the API or individual operation level.
trans-unit.target: Rate limit, quotas, and IP restriction policies can also be implemented at the API or individual operation level.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [How to create APIs][] and [How to add operations to an API][].
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [How to create APIs][] and [How to add operations to an API][].

trans-unit.source: Products
trans-unit.target: Products

trans-unit.source: Products are how APIs are surfaced to developers.
trans-unit.target: Products are how APIs are surfaced to developers.

trans-unit.source: Products in API Management have one or more APIs, and are configured with a title, description, and terms of use.
trans-unit.target: Products in API Management have one or more APIs, and are configured with a title, description, and terms of use.

trans-unit.source: Products can be **Open** or **Protected**.
trans-unit.target: Products can be **Open** or **Protected**.

trans-unit.source: Protected products must be subscribed to before they can be used, while open products can be used without a subscription.
trans-unit.target: Protected products must be subscribed to before they can be used, while open products can be used without a subscription.

trans-unit.source: When a product is ready for use by developers it can be published.
trans-unit.target: When a product is ready for use by developers it can be published.

trans-unit.source: Once it is published, it can be viewed (and in the case of protected products subscribed to) by developers.
trans-unit.target: Once it is published, it can be viewed (and in the case of protected products subscribed to) by developers.

trans-unit.source: Subscription approval is configured at the product level and can either require administrator approval, or be auto-approved.
trans-unit.target: Subscription approval is configured at the product level and can either require administrator approval, or be auto-approved.

trans-unit.source: Groups are used to manage the visibility of products to developers.
trans-unit.target: Groups are used to manage the visibility of products to developers.

trans-unit.source: Products grant visibility to groups, and developers can view and subscribe to the products that are visible to the groups in which they belong.
trans-unit.target: Products grant visibility to groups, and developers can view and subscribe to the products that are visible to the groups in which they belong.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [How to create and publish a product][] and the following video.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [How to create and publish a product][] and the following video.

trans-unit.source: Groups
trans-unit.target: Groups

trans-unit.source: Groups are used to manage the visibility of products to developers.
trans-unit.target: Groups are used to manage the visibility of products to developers.

trans-unit.source: API Management has the following immutable system groups.
trans-unit.target: API Management has the following immutable system groups.

trans-unit.source: **Administrators** - Azure subscription administrators are members of this group.
trans-unit.target: **Administrators** - Azure subscription administrators are members of this group.

trans-unit.source: Administrators manage API Management service instances, creating the APIs, operations, and products that are used by developers.
trans-unit.target: Administrators manage API Management service instances, creating the APIs, operations, and products that are used by developers.

trans-unit.source: **Developers** - Authenticated developer portal users fall into this group.
trans-unit.target: **Developers** - Authenticated developer portal users fall into this group.

trans-unit.source: Developers are the customers that build applications using your APIs.
trans-unit.target: Developers are the customers that build applications using your APIs.

trans-unit.source: Developers are granted access to the developer portal and build applications that call the operations of an API.
trans-unit.target: Developers are granted access to the developer portal and build applications that call the operations of an API.

trans-unit.source: **Guests** - Unauthenticated developer portal users, such as prospective customers visiting the developer portal of an API Management instance fall into this group.
trans-unit.target: **Guests** - Unauthenticated developer portal users, such as prospective customers visiting the developer portal of an API Management instance fall into this group.

trans-unit.source: They can be granted certain read-only access, such as the ability to view APIs but not call them.
trans-unit.target: They can be granted certain read-only access, such as the ability to view APIs but not call them.

trans-unit.source: In addition to these system groups, administrators can create custom groups or [leverage external groups in associated Azure Active Directory tenants](api-management-howto-aad.md/#how-to-add-an-external-azure-active-directory-group).
trans-unit.target: In addition to these system groups, administrators can create custom groups or [leverage external groups in associated Azure Active Directory tenants](api-management-howto-aad.md/#how-to-add-an-external-azure-active-directory-group).

trans-unit.source: Custom and external groups can be used alongside system groups in giving developers visibility and access to API products.
trans-unit.target: Custom and external groups can be used alongside system groups in giving developers visibility and access to API products.

trans-unit.source: For example, you could create one custom group for developers affiliated with a specific partner organization and allow them access to the APIs from a product containing relevant APIs only.
trans-unit.target: For example, you could create one custom group for developers affiliated with a specific partner organization and allow them access to the APIs from a product containing relevant APIs only.

trans-unit.source: A user can be a member of more than one group.
trans-unit.target: A user can be a member of more than one group.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [How to create and use groups][].
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [How to create and use groups][].

trans-unit.source: Developers
trans-unit.target: Developers

trans-unit.source: Developers represent the user accounts in an API Management service instance.
trans-unit.target: Developers represent the user accounts in an API Management service instance.

trans-unit.source: Developers can be created or invited to join by administrators, or they can sign up from the [Developer portal][].
trans-unit.target: Developers can be created or invited to join by administrators, or they can sign up from the [Developer portal][].

trans-unit.source: Each developer is a member of one or more groups, and can be subscribe to the products that grant visibility to those groups.
trans-unit.target: Each developer is a member of one or more groups, and can be subscribe to the products that grant visibility to those groups.

trans-unit.source: When developers subscribe to a product they are granted the primary and secondary key for the product.
trans-unit.target: When developers subscribe to a product they are granted the primary and secondary key for the product.

trans-unit.source: This key is used when making calls into the product's APIs.
trans-unit.target: This key is used when making calls into the product's APIs.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [How to create or invite developers][] and [How to associate groups with developers][].
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [How to create or invite developers][] and [How to associate groups with developers][].

trans-unit.source: Policies
trans-unit.target: Policies

trans-unit.source: Policies are a powerful capability of API Management that allow the publisher to change the behavior of the API through configuration.
trans-unit.target: Policies are a powerful capability of API Management that allow the publisher to change the behavior of the API through configuration.

trans-unit.source: Policies are a collection of statements that are executed sequentially on the request or response of an API.
trans-unit.target: Policies are a collection of statements that are executed sequentially on the request or response of an API.

trans-unit.source: Popular statements include format conversion from XML to JSON and call rate limiting to restrict the amount of incoming calls from a developer, and many other policies are available.
trans-unit.target: Popular statements include format conversion from XML to JSON and call rate limiting to restrict the amount of incoming calls from a developer, and many other policies are available.

trans-unit.source: Policy expressions can be used as attribute values or text values in any of the API Management policies, unless the policy specifies otherwise.
trans-unit.target: Policy expressions can be used as attribute values or text values in any of the API Management policies, unless the policy specifies otherwise.

trans-unit.source: Some policies such as the [Control flow][] and [Set variable][] policies are based on policy expressions.
trans-unit.target: Some policies such as the [Control flow][] and [Set variable][] policies are based on policy expressions.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [Advanced policies][], [Policy expressions][], and watch the following video.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [Advanced policies][], [Policy expressions][], and watch the following video.

trans-unit.source: For a complete list of API Management policies, see [Policy reference][].
trans-unit.target: For a complete list of API Management policies, see [Policy reference][].

trans-unit.source: For more information on using and configuring policies, see [API Management policies][].
trans-unit.target: For more information on using and configuring policies, see [API Management policies][].

trans-unit.source: For a tutorial on creating a product with rate limit and quota policies, see [How create and configure advanced product settings][].
trans-unit.target: For a tutorial on creating a product with rate limit and quota policies, see [How create and configure advanced product settings][].

trans-unit.source: For a demo, see the following video.
trans-unit.target: For a demo, see the following video.

trans-unit.source: Developer portal
trans-unit.target: Developer portal

trans-unit.source: The developer portal is where developers can learn about your APIs, view and call operations, and subscribe to products.
trans-unit.target: The developer portal is where developers can learn about your APIs, view and call operations, and subscribe to products.

trans-unit.source: Prospective customers can visit the developer portal, view APIs and operations, and sign up.
trans-unit.target: Prospective customers can visit the developer portal, view APIs and operations, and sign up.

trans-unit.source: The URL for your developer portal is located on the dashboard in the Azure portal for your API Management service instance.
trans-unit.target: The URL for your developer portal is located on the dashboard in the Azure portal for your API Management service instance.

trans-unit.source: You can customize the look and feel of your developer portal by adding custom content, customizing styles, and adding your branding.
trans-unit.target: You can customize the look and feel of your developer portal by adding custom content, customizing styles, and adding your branding.

trans-unit.source: test
trans-unit.target: test
